results.title: Storm clouds over the colonies
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
Tracing the history of the economic development of colonial territories, this film points out the shift in emphasis from the primary motives of discovery and the transfer of luxury goods to the establishment of permanent industries. The benefits of modern developments are weighed against exploitation, of which colonialism is never free. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.

results.title: They called it white man's burden
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”
Paternalism, with all its problems and achievements among colonial peoples, has a tradition within the Commonwealth which is often misunderstood. This film suggests that the stereotyped picture many people have of colonial officialdom needs revising in the light of Britain’s record. The “Great White Father,” we see, although not oblivious to the material advantages a colony could provide, brought with him, more often than not, a deep sense of responsibility for the welfare of people under his jurisdiction. Noteworthy are campaigns to improve agriculture, alleviate suffering, raise living standards and promote literacy.

results.title: The Jerusalem passion
results.brief_description: Recorded live in the Concert Hall of the Queensland Performing Arts Complex on 9th April 1988. “The Jerusalem passion” was composed and conducted by Christian music director, Murray Wylie and features the Vision One Choir and Orchestra, supported by vocalists Sue Elliott, Jeff Baldock, David Hall, Helen Maguire, Jim McCrystal, Damien Roche, Julie Vidler and Kate Wylie. Playing the pipe organ is Eduarda Van Klinken and the oratorio is narrated by Helen Foster. Vision One is an Australia-wide Christian music initiative.

results.title: The James Dean collector's classic
results.creator_credit: Hollywood House Video and Thirtieth Cemalux
results.brief_description: This is a tribute to one of Hollywood’s most remembered and highly acclaimed actors whose life and career was unfortunately cut short by a tragic car accident. James (or Jimmy) Dean was born in Marion, Indiana in 1931 and died only 24 years later on 30 September 1955. During his short acting career he became a cult hero for the youth of the 50’s, a rebel and an individualist whose sensitive and intense portrayals, particularly in “East of Eden” (1955, dir. Elia Kazan) and “Rebel without a cause” (1955, dir. Nicholas Ray) shot him to legend status almost overnight. Modelling himself on his heroes Marlon Brando and Montgomery Clift, James Dean managed to achieve his own heroic status as a Hollywood star proving that he too could be a great actor in his own right as witnessed in his role in his third feature film, the epic “Giant” (dir. George Stevens), where he starred alongside Elizabeth Taylor, Rock Hudson, Dennis Hopper and Carol Baker. This special Collector’s Classic contains some rare archival newsreel footage, stills, film excerpts from his three feature films, biographical details with personal narratives from friends and actors including Carol Baker, Dennis Hopper, Jack Larson, Natalie Wood among others, career highlights including footage of many of his bit parts in film and television, and finally a complete and uncut version of “The Unlighted road” (1951) which featured in the television series “Schlitz Playhouse of Stars. Backed by the music of Don McLean and “American Pie”, and some wonderful images of the “strange and different…but pure gold” James Dean, this is a most interesting and informative video. NOTE: Due to the unique material contained in this video, fluctuations may occur in picture and sound quality during the program.

results.title: The Invention of the adolescent (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Patricia Watson, Cecily Burwash, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From the past, when distinctions between childhood and adulthood were not as finely drawn as they are today, this film traces the development of the adolescent and shows some of the real problems of this age. It notes that it was the defense of the young, the protection afforded by reformers and educators, that created the generation gap so evident today in Western society. What adolescents gained and lost from changing attitudes towards them is clearly illustrated in the film. (Awards: New York; La Plata; Tehran)

results.title: The Interview [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Craig Monahan, Bill Hughes, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Interview Films
results.brief_description: A haunting feature debut from Craig Monahan which explores the complex psychological exchange between Detective Sergeant John Steele (Tony Martin) and nervy suspected murderer Eddie Fleming (Hugo Weaving) during the hours of a claustrophobic police interrogation.The apparently ordinary Fleming is asleep in his apartment when his door is broken down and he is accused of nameless crimes. He is the only lead the tough, world weary Detective Sergeant Steele has and so begins a bewildering sequence of interviews where the crime and the many forces at work between the characters and their situation gradually becomes apparent. The nature of guilt, innocence and who or what to believe is rendered uncertain in this film as we are presented not with any concrete answers but with the fluidity of perception and the difficulties of defining truth. (Awards: Winner Best Original Screenplay, Best Film and Best Actor (Hugo Weaving) Australian Film Institute Awards, 1998)

results.title: The Island of Nevawuz
results.creator_credit: Paul Williams and Fable Films Productions
results.brief_description: Nevawuz is an idyllic and underdeveloped island in danger of corruption. J.B. Trumphorn, a corporate boss attempts to industrialize the island by using it’s natural source of oil. Aided by the King’s nephew his plan works, polluting the island as a result. Resistance to Trumphorn comes in the form of the young islander, Otto, and his dog Spot, who lead the islanders in a defence of Nevawuz. An instructive and entertaining video for children on the issue of pollution and industrialization. The video also includes “The True story of Ned Kelly” and “Ned Kelly’s dastardly dilemma”. All three tales are written and produced by Paul Williams.

results.title: The Incredible journey
results.creator_credit: Fletcher Markle, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: A holidaying family leave their three pets: Bodger, a bull-terrior; Tao, a Siamese cat; and Luath, a Labrador retriever in charge of a family guest, Emile. When the guest goes off hunting but fails to inform the animals, the three pets begin an incredible journey, over 200 miles to reach their owners. With the majestic Canadian countryside as a backdrop, this film is based on the book by Sheila Burnford. Starring Emile Genest, John Drainie, Tommy Tweed and Sandra Algar.

results.title: The Irishman
results.creator_credit: Donald Crombie, Anthony Buckley and Forest Home Films
results.brief_description: Based on the novel of the same name by Elizabeth O’Connor. Set in Northern Queensland in the 1920’s, it is the story of a proud Irish Australian teamster and his family as they face the competition from motorised transport. This is the story of a family experiencing events which they cannot control in the face of progress and change. Stars Michael Craig, Simon Burke, Robin Nevin and Bryan Brown.
